Then,  I consider the specific harm that the physician alleges the statute causes.  The physician claims that the statute prevents him from giving professional advice to his patients,  which could lead to potential health risks for them.

Based on these considerations,  the physician has a direct stake in the outcome of the case and can demonstrate the harm caused by the statute.  Therefore,  the physician is likely {'sol': 'a'}

Input: A man decided to enroll in a creative writing course at a local adult education facility.  The man signed an agreement with the facility that he would attend weekly classes at the facility for six months and would pay $500  on the first of each month.  Upon signing the contract,  the man made his first payment of $500  and attended the weekly class sessions.  On the first day of the second month,  the man once again made his $500  payment and continued to attend the session.  At the start of the third month,  the man told the director of the facility's accounting office that he was having financial difficulties,  and asked for an extension.  The director agreed to permit the man to attend classes while the man tried to get the money to pay the facility.  One week later,  the man received a letter from the facility informing him that he would be barred from attending any further classes unless the next $500  payment was made.  Is the facility justified in refusing to permit the man to attend classes?  Choices: a) No,  because by permitting the man to attend classes without having paid the third monthly installment,  the facility waived its right to have that installment fee paid on time.  b) No,  because the facility's allowing the man to attend classes without paying the third monthly installment created an implied contract,  thus permitting him to complete the classes without advance payment of the installments.  c) Yes,  because the man's failure to make the third monthly installment payment constituted an anticipatory breach.  d) Yes,  because there was no consideration to extinguish the payment of the third monthly installment fee,  which was a material part of the contract.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the contract between the man and the facility.  The contract required the man to pay $500  on the first of each month and attend weekly classes for six months.  The man made his first two payments and attended the classes,  fulfilling the contract terms.
 At the start of the third month,  the man informed the facility of his financial difficulties and asked for an extension.  The facility agreed to permit the man to attend classes while he tried to pay.
 However,  one week later,  the facility informed the man that he would be barred from attending any further classes unless the next $500  payment was made.
 Now,  I need to consider the options given.
 a) This option suggests that the facility waived its right to have the third installment paid on time by permitting the man to attend classes without the payment.  This could be a valid argument,  as the facility's decision to allow the man to attend classes without the payment might have waived its right to have the payment made on time.
 b) This option suggests that the facility's allowing the man to attend classes without paying the third monthly installment created an implied contract.  An implied contract is one that is inferred from the conduct of the parties,  and it is not explicitly stated in the contract.  In this case,  the facility's decision to allow the man to attend classes without the payment might have created an implied contract,  but it is not explicitly stated in the contract.
 c) This option suggests that the man's failure to make the third monthly installment payment constituted an anticipatory breach.  An anticipatory breach occurs when one party to a contract indicates that it will not fulfill its obligations under the contract.  In this case,  the man's failure to make the third monthly installment payment could be considered an anticipatory breach,  as he informed the facility of his financial difficulties and asked for an extension.
 d) This option suggests that there was no consideration to extinguish the payment of the third monthly installment fee,  which was a material part of theOutput: {'sol': 'c'}

Input: During the final days of his presidency,  many of the President's Cabinet members began leaking rather embarrassing stories about the President to the press.  In one such story,  which appeared in a newspaper,  an unidentified Cabinet member was quoted as saying that the President pardoned the owner of a professional baseball team,  for a previous felony conviction because the owner promised to give the President a lifetime pass to all future games.  Upset by these news "leaks, " the President,  in his last official act,  issued an executive order banning all executive employees from having conversations with members of the press unless prior permission had been obtained from an administrative supervisor.  The executive order called for the dismissal of any employee willfully in violation of that order.  After the President left office,  the press made repeated references to the executive order and derisively referred to it as the President's legacy.  Nonetheless,  after the new President took office he promised to abide by the order.  Thereafter one of the Vice President's senior advisers,  leaked a story to a magazine stating that the Vice President told staff members that the only reason he visited a city following an earthquake was because he wanted to play golf at a nearby golf course.  The magazine printed the story and named the senior adviser as the source.  In compliance with civil service regulations,  a hearing was conducted and the senior adviser was found to have violated the executive order barring unauthorized conununications with print media.  Subsequently,  the senior adviser was summarily dismissed from his executive staff position.  The senior adviser brings an appropriate action seeking reinstatement and challenges the constitutionality of the executive order.  If this case reaches the U.  S.  Supreme Court,  the justices should rule the executive order is Choices: a) constitutional,  because governmental employment is a privilege and not a right.  b) constitutional,  because the President has plenary power to set forth employment regulations for executive department employees.  c) unconstitutional,  because Congress,  not the President,  has authority to regulate the terms and conditions of federal employment.  d) unconstitutional,  because the President cannot broadly limit all executive employees' freedom of speech and association.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the nature of the executive order.  The order was issued by the President to restrict conversations between executive employees and members of the press without prior permission from an administrative supervisor.
 Next,  I need to consider the authority of the President.  The President has plenary power to set forth employment regulations for executive department employees.
 Finally,  I need to consider the constitutionality of the executive order.  The order does not broadly limit all executive employees' freedom of speech and association,  but rather restricts conversations with members of the press without permission.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A national association brought suit in federal court against a city.  The suit charged the city with violating several federal statutes.  First,  I need to consider the context of the trial.  This is a federal court trial,  so the relevant privilege law should be related to federal law.
 Next,  I need to consider the location of the trial.  The trial is in the federal court,  so the forum state is not relevant in this case.
 Finally,  I need to consider the purpose of the privilege.  The attorney-client privilege is meant to protect confidential communications between a client and their attorney.
 Based on these considerations,  the issues raised by the city attorney's objections should be resolved under federal privilege law.  Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'a'}

Input: Two brothers broke into the home of a bank's president and kidnapped the president's wife. As the wife was driving down the street,  a woman pushing her baby in a stroller suddenly stopped in the middle of the intersection. If the wife is subsequently prosecuted for the murder of the bystander,  she will most likely be found Choices: a) guilty,  because she intentionally veered the car,  striking the bystander.  b) not guilty,  by reason of necessity.  c) not guilty,  by reason of duress.  d) not guilty,  by reason of self-defense.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the circumstances under which the wife acted.  She was being held hostage by the brothers,  and her safety and that of her family depended on their demands being met.  This creates a situation of duress,  where she is forced to make difficult decisions under threat of harm.

Next,  I need to evaluate the actions taken by the wife.  She intentionally veered the car to the left to avoid hitting the woman and her child.  This action was necessary to prevent a greater harm,  as hitting the woman and her child would have caused more damage than striking the bystander.

Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'c'}

Input: A defendant was going out to dinner,  and she parked her car at a parking lot across the street from the restaurant.  The parking attendant directed the defendant to leave her keys in the car,  and he handed her a receipt as she left.  Following dinner,  the defendant went back to the parking lot and handed her receipt to the attendant who informed her that the parking charge would be $14.  Visibly irate,  she told the attendant that $14  was much too high for a two-hour parking fee.  The parking attendant responded that unless she paid the $14,  he could not return her car.  She adamantly refused to pay the $14,  and her friend,  with whom she was having dinner,  drove the defendant home in her car.  Later that same night,  the defendant decided to regain possession of her car with a spare set of keys.  She returned to the lot and drove her car home.  If the defendant is subsequently charged with larceny,  she will most likely be found Choices: a) guilty,  because she failed to pay the $14  before regaining possession of her car.  b) guilty,  because she was under a binding contractual obligation to pay the parking fee.  c) not guilty,  because the $14  charge was excessively high.  d) not guilty,  because the defendant cannot be charged with larceny of her own motor vehicle.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the legal principles involved in this scenario.  Larceny is the unlawful taking and carrying away of personal property belonging to another with the intent to steal.  In this case,  the defendant's actions of driving her car home without paying the $14  parking fee could be seen as an act of larceny.
 Next,  I need to consider the defendant's argument that the $14  charge was excessively high.  While this may be a valid argument,  it does not negate her legal obligation to pay the fee if she wished to reclaim her car.
 Now,  I need to consider the defendant's argument that she cannot be charged with larceny of her own motor vehicle.  While the vehicle is technically her property,  the parking lot is private property,  and she entered into a contractual agreement with the parking lot to park her vehicle there.
 Finally,  I need to consider the defendant's actions of refusing to pay the $14  parking fee before regaining possession of her car.  This refusal to pay the agreed-upon fee is an act of larceny,  as it involves taking the property (the use of the parking space) without paying for it.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'a'}

Input: A grantor conveyed his property to his son "for life,  remainder after (the son's) death to his heirs.  " Two years later,  the son entered into a real estate agreement for the sale of the property to his friend,  whereby the son agreed to convey the premises to his friend in fee simple absolute.  Prior to the settlement date,  the friend contacted the son,  telling him that he would not perform his part of the agreement because the son could not convey a fee simple.  If the Rule in Shelley's Case is followed in this jurisdiction,  the outcome of a suit by the son for specific performance of the real estate contract would result in Choices: a) the son's not succeeding,  because he could not convey marketable title.  b) the son's succeeding,  because he had a fee simple to convey.  c) the son's not succeeding,  because his heirs have to join in the transaction in order to convey marketable title.  d) the son's succeeding,  because the son's conveyance of his life estate to the friend divested the contingent remainder of his heirs.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to understand the legal terms involved.  The grantor conveyed his property to his son with a life estate,  meaning the son could use the property for his entire life,  but after his death,  the property would go to his heirs.  The son then entered into a real estate agreement to sell the property to his friend,  with the intention of conveying the property to his friend in fee simple absolute,  meaning the friend would own the property outright.
 The Rule in Shelley's Case is a legal principle that states that a person with a life estate cannot convey a fee simple absolute to another person,  because the contingent remainder (the son's heirs) has an interest in the property that is not divested by the life estate transfer.
 Now,  I need to consider the choices given.  Choice a) suggests that the son would not succeed because he could not convey marketable title,  which is related to the Rule in Shelley's Case.  Choice b) suggests that the son would succeed because he had a fee simple to convey,  which is not correct due to the Rule in Shelley's Case.  Choice c) suggests that the son would not succeed because his heirs have to join in the transaction,  which is not directly related to the Rule in Shelley's Case.  Choice d) suggests that the son would succeed because the son's conveyance of his life estate to the friend divested the contingent remainder of his heirs,  which is also not correct due to the Rule in Shelley's Case.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'a'}

Input: A man entered a local retail store and approached the proprietor.  The man explained that he was participating in a local run for charity and wondered if the proprietor would be interested in sponsoring him.  The proprietor believed the publicity would be good for his business and agreed,  provided the man would wear a shirt with the retail store's logo on it during the run.  The man readily agreed.  The proprietor thought that sponsorship meant paying a set fee for every mile covered during the charity run.  However,  the man expected the proprietor,  in addition to paying the fee for each mile coverÃ§d during the run,  to also pay his entrance fee and be in attendance at the finish line to greet the man when he finished the charity run.  Assume that the man and the proprietor entered into an enforceable contract.  Which of the following,  if true,  would not help to establish that the manifestations of the parties were operative according to the meaning adjudged by the proprietor?  Choices: a) The customary practice of the other chrity runs in the community is the same as the proprietor's understanding,  that the sponsor be responsible for paying only a set fee for each mile covered during the charity run.  b) A reasonably objective individual would have attached the same meaning to the manifestations of the parties as did the proprietor.  c) At the time the agreement was entered into,  the man had reason to know the proprietor's understanding of what the parties meant,  although the proprietor did not know the man's understanding was different from his.  d) The proprietor subjectively believed that the man understood that the proprietor would only be obligated to pay a set fee for each mile covered during the charity run.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to understand the proprietor's understanding of the sponsorship agreement.  The proprietor believed that sponsorship meant paying a set fee for every mile covered during the charity run.
 Next,  I need to understand the man's expectations from the sponsorship agreement.  The man expected the proprietor to pay the fee for each mile covered during the run,  his entrance fee,  and be in attendance at the finish line to greet him when he finished the charity run.
 Now,  I need to determine which of the given choices would not help to establish that the manifestations of the parties were operative according to the proprietor's understanding.
 a) If the customary practice in the community is the same as the proprietor's understanding,  it would support the proprietor's interpretation of the agreement.
 b) If a reasonably objective individual would have attached the same meaning to the manifestations of the parties as did the proprietor,  it would also support the proprietor's interpretation of the agreement.
 c) If the man had reason to know the proprietor's understanding and the proprietor did not know the man's understanding was different,  it would suggest that the proprietor's interpretation was the common understanding between the parties.
 d) If the proprietor subjectively believed that the man understood the proprietor's interpretation,  it would not necessarily establish that the man agreed to the proprietor's interpretation,  as the man's actual understanding was different.

Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'd'}

Input: Two men agreed to burglarize a home.  While they were planning the burglary,  the two men learned that the home had a sophisticated alarm system that needed to be disarmed.  One of the men told the other that he knew an alarm specialist who could help disarm the security system.  One of the men then approached the alarm specialist and asked if he would assist them in disarming the home's alarm system.  The alarm specialist said that he didn't want to participate in the crime but told the man how he could disarm the system himself.  The two men thereafter went to the home to commit the burglary.  When they arrived at the home,  they saw a vicious guard dog patrolling the fenced-in area of the home.  Deciding it would be too risky to confront the dog,  the two men abandoned their planned burglary.  Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the criminal liability of the two men and the alarm specialist?  Choices: a) The two men are guilty of conspiracy.  b) The two men and the alarm specialist are guilty of conspiracy.  c) The two men are guilty of conspiracy and the two men and the alarm specialist are guilty of attempted burglary.  d) The two men and the alarm specialist are guilty of both conspiracy and attempted burglary.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to determine the criminal liability of the two men.  They planned to commit burglary and even approached the alarm specialist to help them with the plan,  which means they are guilty of conspiracy.
 Next,  I need to consider the criminal liability of the alarm specialist.  Although he didn't want to participate in the crime,  he provided information that would help the two men commit the burglary.  This means he is also guilty of conspiracy.
 Finally,  I need to consider the criminal liability of the two men and the alarm specialist in relation to the attempted burglary.  Since they all planned the burglary and were on the way to commit it,  they are guilty of attempted burglary.
 Therefore,  the most accurate statement is that the two men and the alarm specialist are guilty of both conspiracy and attempted burglary.  The correct answer is {'sol': 'd'}

Input: A man drinks a great deal of punch at a party.  He was unaware that it contained PCP.  Later in the evening,  in an uncontrollable psychotic rage brought on by the drugs he kills someone at the party.  The prosecution asks for second degree murder.  What defense would have the best chance to succeed under the circumstances?  Choices: a) Voluntary intoxication b) Irresistible Impulse c) Involuntary intoxication d) Ignorance or Mistake 
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the legal defenses that could potentially be used in this case.  The options given are voluntary intoxication,  irresistible impulse,  involuntary intoxication,  and ignorance or mistake.
 Next,  I need to consider which of these defenses would be most likely to succeed in this specific situation.  The man was unaware that the punch contained PCP and that it caused his psychotic rage.
 Now,  I need to evaluate each defense option.  Voluntary intoxication is not likely to be successful because the man was unaware of the drug's presence.  Irresistible impulse might be a possibility,  but it is less likely to be successful because the man's actions were caused by the drug,  which is not the same as an irresistible impulse that is not caused by any external factor.  Involuntary intoxication is not a valid defense because the man was unaware of the drug's presence,  but he was not unaware of his actions.  Ignorance or mistake is the most plausible defense because the man had no knowledge of the PCP in the punch.
 Therefore,  the best defense in this case would be {'sol': 'd'}

Input: A defendant is on trial for bribing a government procurement officer by providing the officer with free vacation facilities.  Output:
 First,  I need to consider the nature of the statement made by the defendant.  The statement is a threat to provide information in exchange for the investigator's promise to stop worrying about the vacation.  This statement was made in a negotiation for settlement of a criminal investigation.
 Next,  I need to determine if this type of statement is admissible under the rules of evidence.  The statement falls under the category of a statement made in a negotiation for settlement of a criminal investigation,  which is generally not admissible.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A farmer was the fee-simple owner of a tract of land inthe country.  The farmer moved to the city in 1986.  Aman took possession of the land in 1987  as an adversepossessor and remained on the land from 1987  to 1997 ;he then left the property to care for his sick mother forone year,  returning the following year,  1999.  Assume that the statutory period for adverse possession in this state is 20  years.  In 2010,  the farmer wanted to move back to the tract because he desired to return to the country.  Finding the man in possession,  the farmer initiated a suit in ejectment against the man.  The most probable judicial determination would be Choices: a) the farmer would lose,  because the man's possession was open,  hostile,  and continuous.  b) the farmer would lose,  because the man had fulfilled the required statutory period to become an adverse possessor.  c) the farmer would win,  because the man's possession was not continuous.  d) the farmer would win,  because he is the titleholder of record.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the requirements for adverse possession.  In this case,  the statutory period is 20  years.  The adverse possessor must have possessed the land openly,  hostilely,  and continuously for the statutory period.
 Next,  I need to analyze the man's possession.  He took possession in 1987  and remained on the land until 1997,  which is 10  years.  He then left the property for one year,  returning in 1999.  This means his possession was not continuous for the full 20  years.
 Considering the requirements for adverse possession,  the man did not fulfill the continuous possession requirement.
 Therefore,  the most probable judicial determination would be that the farmer would win,  because the man's possession was not continuous.  The correct answer is {'sol': 'c'}

Input: A man claims to have inherited property from a wealthy businessman.  The man's birth certificate shows that he was born out of wedlock.  The record of a proceeding for a support order shows that the businessman was adjudged to be father of the man.  However,  the man can establish his status as heir of the businessman only if he was legitimated by the marriage of his mother and the businessman subsequent to his birth.  Thus,  the man must prove that this marriage occurred.  The man's attorney has not been able to discover any marriage license or certificate.  However,  the attorney does have a photograph that shows a couple dressed in wedding clothes.  The scene is the front of a church.  Bystanders are seen to be throwing rice at the couple and they seem to be responding by smiling and bowing down.  The attorney was given the photograph by the man.  He found it in his mother's effects following her death.  The man believes that the bride in the picture is his mother.  He cannot identify the groom.  The attorney was informed by a former acquaintance of the businessman who has seen the snapshot that he thinks the groom is the businessman.  If the attorney seeks to introduce the photograph as proof that the mother and the businessman were married,  the trial judge should rule the photograph Choices: a) admissible,  only if the photographer is available to testify concerning the circumstances under which the photograph was taken.  b) admissible,  only if a witness verifies that it is a correct and accurate representation of the relevant facts.  c) inadmissible as non-verbal hearsay not within any recognized exception.  d) inadmissible as not the best evidence.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the admissibility of the photograph as evidence of the marriage.  The photograph shows a couple dressed in wedding clothes,  with bystanders throwing rice and the couple smiling and bowing down,  which suggests a wedding ceremony.  The attorney has been given the photograph by the man,  who believes that the bride is his mother and the groom is the businessman.  A former acquaintance of the businessman also believes that the groom is the businessman.

Next,  I need to consider the rules for admitting photographs as evidence.  Photographs can be admitted as evidence if they are relevant and if they are a reliable representation of the facts they are intended to prove.  In this case,  the photograph is relevant to the man's claim of inheritance,  and the attorney believes it is a reliable representation of the wedding ceremony.

Now,  I need to consider the options for admitting the photograph as evidence.  Option a) requires the availability of the photographer to testify about the circumstances of the photograph.  Option b) requires a witness to verify that the photograph is a correct and accurate representation of the relevant facts.  Option c) considers the photograph inadmissible as non-verbal hearsay not within any recognized exception.  Option d) considers the photograph inadmissible as not the best evidence.

Based on the information provided,  the most appropriate option is b) admissible,  only if a witness verifies that it is a correct and accurate representation of the relevant facts.  This is because the photograph is relevant and potentially reliable,  but the attorney needs to ensure that it accurately represents the marriage between the man's mother and the businessman.

Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: Seller says a circumstance has occurred that makes performing a sales contract impractical.  Which of the following is not correct about discharge for impracticability?  Choices: a) The problem must not have been caused by the fault of the party seeking to invoke the defense.  b) A price increase is sufficient for discharge.  c) The failure to excuse performance would result in grave injustice.  d) The impracticality must go to a basic assumption on which the contract was made.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to understand the concept of discharge for impracticability.  This is a legal defense that allows a party to terminate a contract if a circumstance arises that makes performance impractical.
 Next,  I need to analyze each choice and see if it is a correct statement about discharge for impracticability.
 a) The problem must not have been caused by the party seeking to invoke the defense.  This is correct because the party invoking the defense must not be responsible for the impracticability.
 b) A price increase is sufficient for discharge.  This is not necessarily correct because a price increase alone may not necessarily make performance impractical.
 c) The failure to excuse performance would result in grave injustice.  This is correct because the law generally favors avoiding grave injustice.
 d) The impracticality must go to a basic assumption on which the contract was made.  This is correct because the impracticability must be related to a fundamental assumption of the contract.

Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A woman inherited her father's farm when he died testate.  Prior to her father's death,  the woman had already taken over the operations on the father's farm due to his declining health.  Recently,  the woman had granted a coal company rights to strip-mine coal from underneath the farm.  Their agreement stipulated that the coal company would pay the woman a per-ton royalty for the coal extracted.  In addition,  the coal company agreed to fill in the excavated area and replace top soil on the surface of the land.  After the coal company commenced its strip-mining operations,  the woman noticed that the company was not filling in the excavated area as previously agreed.  However,  because the company paid the woman all the coal royalties from the strip mining,  she did not voice any objection regarding its failure to replace the top soil.  Two years later,  the coal company had now completed its strip-mining operation under its arrangement with the woman.  The coal company's right to strip-mine coal from the woman's property would be an example of a (an) Choices: a) profit-a-prendre.  b) license.  c) easement in gross.  d) voluntary waste.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to understand the nature of the relationship between the woman and the coal company.  The woman had already taken over the farm operations before her father's death,  and the coal company has the right to strip-mine coal from the farm.
 Next,  I need to consider the terms of the agreement.  The coal company pays the woman a per-ton royalty for the coal extracted and agrees to fill in the excavated area and replace top soil on the surface of the land.
 Now,  I need to identify the type of right the coal company has.  A profit-a-prendre is a right to use another's property for one's own benefit without any obligation to compensate the owner.  A license is a right to use another's property for a specific purpose, with the owner retaining ownership.  An easement in gross is a right to use another's property for a specific purpose, with the owner retaining ownership, and the right can be transferred to a third party.  Voluntary waste is a situation where a party damages another's property intentionally.
 In this case,  the coal company has a right to use the woman's property to extract coal, with the condition of paying a royalty and filling in the excavated area.  The woman retains ownership of the property,  and the right to use the property is not transferable to a third party.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: Three friends decided to go bowling together.  They made a friendly wager on the match,  with the winner receiving a free beer from the other two guys.  In the second frame of the first game,  the first friend apparently got a strike when he knocked down all 10  pins.  However,  the second friend accused the first friend of fouling because his foot went over the line.  The first friend denied fouling and wanted to mark down a strike on the scorecard.  The second friend refused to give the first friend a strike and wrote in a zero on the scoring sheet.  The first friend became enraged.  The second friend then went to bowl his frame.  As the second friend turned his back,  the first friend approached from behind with a bowling ball in his hand.  The first friend then raised the bowling ball threatening to hit the back of the second friend's head.  The second friend,  who had his back turned,  did not see the first friend's actions.  The third friend saw what the first friend was about to do and could easily have warned the second friend; but the third friend remained silent.  The first friend then struck the second friend on the back of the head with the bowling ball,  causing a deep scalp wound.  If the second friend asserts a cause of action against the third friend,  he should Choices: a) prevail,  because the third friend was aware of the danger.  b) prevail,  on account of the third friend's omission to act.  c) not prevail,  because the first friend was responsible for his injury.  d) not prevail,  because the third friend was under no duty to warn the second friend of the danger.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the legal principles at play here.  This situation involves the concept of "duty to warn" or "duty to protect." In many jurisdictions,  a person who knows of a potential harm to another person has a duty to warn or protect that person,  especially if the person has a relationship of trust or confidence.
 Next,  I need to consider the relationship between the friends.  They are friends who went bowling together and made a friendly wager,  so they have a relationship of trust and confidence.
 Now,  I need to consider the third friend's actions.  The third friend saw what the first friend was about to do and could easily have warned the second friend,  but the third friend remained silent.
 Finally,  I need to match the legal principles to the facts of the case.  The third friend had a duty to warn the second friend of the danger,  but failed to do so.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A police officer stopped a driver who had run a red light.  Upon approaching the car,  the officer noticed a strong odor of alcohol and immediately asked whether the driver had been drinking.  The driver admitted having had several alcoholic drinks that evening.  The driver,  charged with driving while intoxicated,  moved to suppress the officer's testimony regarding the driver's statement about his drinking.  The driver argued that the officer had elicited the statement without providing the requisite Miranda warnings.  The prosecutor has responded that the statement The prosecutor has responded that the statement should be allowed in the prosecution's case-in- chief or,  at a minimum,  should be allowed as impeachment in the event the driver testifies and denies drinking.  How should the court rule regarding the driver's statement admitting his drinking?  Choices: a) The statement should be allowed,  because although the driver was in custody,  the officer's spontaneous utterance upon smelling alcohol did not rise to the level of interrogation.  b) The statement should be allowed,  because the driver was not in custody for Miranda purposes when the admission was made.  c) The statement should be suppressed both in the prosecution's case-in-chief and as impeachment evidence,  even if the driver testifies.  d) The statement should be suppressed in the prosecution's case-in-chief,  but it may be prosecution's case-in-chief,  but it may be used as impeachment evidence if the driver testifies.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider whether the driver was in custody for Miranda purposes at the time of the statement.  The driver was stopped for running a red light and was asked about drinking,  which suggests that he was not yet in formal custody but was still in a investigatory stage.  Therefore,  the driver was not in custody for Miranda purposes when the admission was made.
 Next,  I need to determine whether the statement was the result of interrogation.  The officer asked the driver whether he had been drinking,  which is a question designed to elicit information from the driver.  Therefore,  the statement was the result of interrogation.
 Finally,  I need to consider the implications of the driver's status and the nature of the statement.  Since the driver was not in custody for Miranda purposes and the statement was the result of interrogation,  the statement should be suppressed in the prosecution's case-in-chief.
 However,  the statement may still be used as impeachment evidence if the driver testifies and denies drinking.  This is because the fact that the driver admitted to drinking is relevant to his credibility.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'd'}

Input: A farmer has a large field where he grows corn.  He hires a crop-duster to spray the field,  but the crop- duster mistakenly sprays a strong herbicide,  rather than a pesticide,  and kills all the corn plants in the field.  Several days later,  a construction company building a house near the farmer's field negligently hits a gas line and starts a fire that burns everything in the area,  including the farmer's field.  If the farmer brings negligence claims against the crop-duster and the construction company in order to recover damages for the destruction of his corn crop,  the most likely result is Choices: a) only the crop-duster is liable,  because its negligence occurred before the construction company's negligence.  b) only the construction company is liable,  because its negligence would have destroyed the farmer's corn crop no matter what the crop- duster did.  c) both the crop-duster and the construction company are liable,  because each engaged in a negligent action that was sufficient to destroy the farmer's corn crop.  d) neither the crop-duster nor the construction company is liable,  because neither is a "but for" cause of the harm.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the sequence of events and the role of each party.  The crop-duster's negligence in spraying the herbicide directly led to the death of the corn plants,  which were then destroyed by the fire caused by the construction company's negligence.
 Next,  I need to evaluate the causal link between each party's negligence and the harm suffered by the farmer.  The crop-duster's action was necessary for the farmer's corn crop to be destroyed,  as the plants would not have died without the herbicide.  The construction company's action was also necessary for the farmer's corn crop to be destroyed,  as the fire would not have occurred without their negligence.
 Finally,  I need to consider whether each party's negligence was sufficient on its own to cause the harm.  The herbicide applied by the crop-duster was strong enough to kill the corn plants,  and the fire caused by the construction company's negligence was extensive enough to destroy everything in the area,  including the farmer's field.
 Therefore,  the most likely result is that both the crop-duster and the construction company are liable,  because each engaged in a negligent action that was sufficient to destroy the farmer's corn crop.  This corresponds to choice c) both the crop-duster and the construction company are liable,  because each engaged in a negligent action that was sufficient to destroy the farmer's corn crop.  

Output: {'sol': 'c'}

Input: A defendant incurred heavy gambling losses to a bookie.  Short of cash,  the defendant sought help from his uncle.  When the uncle refused to lend his irresponsible nephew any money,  the defendant decided to get even.  One morning,  as the housekeeper was preparing his uncle's breakfast,  the defendant stealthily entered the kitchen and,  unnoticed,  dropped arsenic into the teapot from which his uncle was always served his tea.  The defendant then hurriedly left the house and went to play golf.  Shortly thereafter,  the housekeeper served the uncle the poisoned tea,  thus causing his unfortunate death.  The defendant's culpability for his uncle's death would most probably be as Choices: a) an accessory before the fact.  b) a principal in the first degree.  c) a principal in the second degree.  d) an accomplice.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to determine the defendant's role in the death of his uncle.  The defendant intentionally poisoned the tea,  knowing it would harm his uncle.  This shows premeditation and intent.
 Next,  I need to consider the actions of the housekeeper.  The housekeeper served the poisoned tea to the uncle,  acting as an agent in the poisoning.
 To find the defendant's culpability,  I look at the level of involvement and intent.  The defendant was the one who committed the act of poisoning,  making him directly responsible for the death.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: Congress enacted a statute designed to make the stabilization of rents more effective throughout the United States.  The statute will be applicable to all leasehold contracts hereafter entered into between landlords and tenants involving residential and commercial properties.  The new federal statute is intended to protect tenants from spiraling rents and "profiteering" by landlords without curtailing the supply of rental units or depriving landlords of substantial constitutional rights.  The new federal statute would be most clearly constitutional as applied to Choices: a) the rental of a state-owned office building by a state to a privately owned business.  b) the rental of residential property located in the District of Columbia by an individual landlord to a family of six.  c) the rental of an apartment located by a real estate company to an individual tenant.  d) the rental of an office building to a city by an individual landlord.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the purpose of the new federal statute,  which is to stabilize rents and protect tenants from spiraling rents and profiteering by landlords.
 Next,  I need to consider the applicability of the statute to each choice.  The statute applies to leasehold contracts between landlords and tenants involving residential and commercial properties.
 a) The rental of a state-owned office building by a state to a privately owned business is not a leasehold contract between a landlord and a tenant,  so the statute does not apply.
 b) The rental of residential property located in the District of Columbia by an individual landlord to a family of six is a leasehold contract involving a residential property,  so the statute applies.
 c) The rental of an apartment located by a real estate company to an individual tenant is a leasehold contract involving a residential property,  so the statute applies.
 d) The rental of an office building to a city by an individual landlord is not a leasehold contract between a landlord and a tenant,  so the statute does not apply.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A mother whose child had birth defects sued the pharmaceutical company that made the purportedly dangerous drug prescribed to her during pregnancy.  At trial,  she offered an expert witness to prove that the drug was a substantial factor in causing the baby's injuries.  The expert was a Ph. D.  medical researcher with an additional degree in computer science.  He had experience in the research and development of similar drugs for other large pharmaceutical companies.  He had published relevant articles in peer review journals describing the dangers of these types of drugs.  The findings were endorsed by other experts in the field.  On the subject litigation,  he performed a differential diagnosis,  conducted several scientifically valid tests,  and made various calculations.  He concluded that the drug was the culprit in this case.  The Defendants made a Daubert motion challenging the witness' qualifications and the reliability of his testimony,  arguing he was a mere researcher and not a physician.  Is the court likely to grant the motion and preclude the witness as an expert?  Choices: a) Yes,  the proposed testimony was not reliable in that it was based on scientific testing only and did not discuss medical science or rule out other causes.  b) No,  the testimony was admissible because several factors militated in favor of the expert's opinion being reliable,  and thus helpful to the jury in determining the critical issue of causation.  c) Yes,  the proposed testimony was inadmissible because it was general and did not tie in the expert's knowledge with the case being litigated.  d) No,  the testimony was admissible because the expert's opinion was so authoritative that the court would order the jury to adopt its findings as a matter of law.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the Daubert standard,  which requires the court to determine if the expert's testimony is reliable and relevant to the case.  The expert in this case has a Ph. D.  in medical research,  an additional degree in computer science,  and has experience in the research and development of similar drugs.  He has published relevant articles in peer review journals and his findings were endorsed by other experts in the field.  He also performed a differential diagnosis,  conducted several scientifically valid tests,  and made various calculations.

Next,  I need to consider the Defendants' argument that the expert is not qualified to testify because he is not a physician.  However,  the fact that he has a Ph. D.  in medical research and has experience in the field suggests that he is qualified to testify as an expert.

Finally,  I need to consider whether the testimony is relevant to the case.  The expert's testimony addresses the causation issue,  and his findings were based on scientific testing and calculations.  The testimony is relevant and helpful to the jury in determining the critical issue of causation.

Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A state in which several popular ski resorts are located has enacted a law requiring state certification of ski instructors.  Under the law,  applicants for certification must attend a monthlong course,  pass a test,  and pay a fee of $1,000.  The stated purpose of the law is to "promote uniformity in the methods of ski instruction at the state's ski areas. " Shortly before the law's enactment,  when the state did not require certification of ski instructors,  a woman moved to the state intending to find employment as a ski instructor.  The woman had been a ski instructor in another state for many years.  But since her move,  even though ski resorts in the state have found her to be highly qualified,  no resort will offer her a contract for employment as a ski instructor because she has not received the required state certification.  As applied to the woman,  does the state certification requirement constitute a violation of the contracts clause?  Choices: a) No,  because her ability to contract for employment with the state is not being impaired.  b) No,  because she has no existing contract that is being impaired.  c) Yes,  because,  as applied to an otherwise qualified ski instructor,  the requirement is not rationally related to a legitimate government interest.  d) Yes,  because the requirement substantially impairs her ability to contract for employment in the absence of an important government objective.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the contracts clause,  which is part of the Constitution's Bill of Rights.  The clause states that "No State shall . . . pass any Bill of Attainder,  or ex post facto Law,  or Law impairing the Obligation of Contracts,  or grant any Title of Nobility."
 Next,  I need to determine if the state certification requirement impairs the woman's ability to contract for employment.  The requirement is preventing her from obtaining a ski instructor position,  so it is limiting her ability to contract for employment.
 Now,  I need to consider if there is a legitimate government interest behind the requirement.  The stated purpose is to promote uniformity in ski instruction methods,  which could be seen as a legitimate interest.
 Finally,  I need to determine if the requirement is rationally related to the legitimate interest.  The requirement may contribute to promoting uniformity,  but it also substantially impairs the woman's ability to contract for employment,  who is already qualified as a ski instructor.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'd'}

Input: A man was driving his new car along a dark road with the car's high-beam headlights on to illuminate the road.  When he saw the headlights of another car appear in the distance,  he reached to turn the high beams off.  Instead of turning from high-beam to low-beam,  the headlights on the car turned off completely.  The man tried repeatedly to turn the lights on again but could not do so.  He collided with the other car and suffered injuries.  The man has brought an action against the manufacturer of the headlight controls in his car,  the manufacturer of his car,  and the retailer who sold him the car.  If the man can establish that a defect in the controls caused the accident,  from whom can he recover?  Choices: a) Only the manufacturer of the car and the retailer of the car.  b) Only the manufacturer of the car.  c) Only the manufacturer of the headlight controls and the manufacturer of the car.  d) All three defendants.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the potential liability for the accident.  The man claims that a defect in the headlight controls caused the accident.  If he can establish that,  then the liability would typically fall on the party responsible for the defect.
 Next,  I need to consider the potential defendants.  The man is suing the manufacturer of the headlight controls,  the manufacturer of the car,  and the retailer who sold him the car.
 Now,  I need to consider the possible causes of the defect.  The defect could be in the headlight controls themselves,  or it could be in the integration of the headlight controls into the car,  or it could be in the car's design that affects the operation of the headlight controls.
 To determine from whom the man can recover,  I need to consider the legal principle of "chain of causation." This principle states that the party responsible for the defect is the one from whom recovery can be sought. In this case, if the defect is in the headlight controls themselves, the man can recover from the manufacturer of the headlight controls. If the defect is in the integration of the headlight controls into the car, both the manufacturer of the headlight controls and the manufacturer of the car could be liable. If the defect is in the car's design that affects the operation of the headlight controls, the manufacturer of the car would be liable.
 In this scenario, the man can establish that a defect in the controls caused the accident. Therefore, if the defect is in the headlight controls themselves, he can recover from the manufacturer of the headlight controls. If the defect is in the integration of the headlight controls into the car, he can recover from both the manufacturer of the headlight controls and the manufacturer of the car. If the defect is in the car's design that affects the operation of the headlight controls, he can recover from the manufacturer of the car.
 Therefore, the correct answer is {'sol': 'd'}

Input: A family had been traveling cross-country on a camping trip when they decided to pull into Yellowstone National Park.  During their stay at Yellowstone,  the family camped out in a secluded area of the campgrounds surrounded by tall pine trees.  Numerous signs had been posted throughout the campgrounds warning campers of the extremely dry conditions prevailing in the forest area due to a summerlong drought.  On the morning of their departure,  the family cooked breakfast over an open campfire.  After breakfast,  the family began to pack their gear into the van when the father instructed his 12 -year-old son to put out the campfire.  The son fetched two pails of water from a nearby pond and tossed the water over the campfire.  Believing that he had extinguished the fire,  the son joined his family in the van,  and they drove away.  Unbeknownst to the son and his family,  the campfire was still smoldering when they left.  Shortly thereafter,  a wind gust blew the flames from the fire to some nearby brush.  Due to the extremely dry conditions,  the brush quickly ignited,  starting a raging forest fire.  The forest rangers dispatched a firefighting team,  which included two helicopters equipped to fight the fire.  While these helicopters were fighting the blaze from above,  the smoke ¢ surrounding one of the helicopters became so intense that the pilot lost all visibility.  At the same time,  an operator of a small private plane saw the blaze and recklessly descended into the smoke.  In the pilot's attempt to veer out of the intense smoke,  his helicopter collided with the operator's low- flying plane,  causing the aircrafts to crash.  Both the pilot and the operator were killed in the resulting explosion.  In a wrongful death action brought by the pilot's estate against the son and the father,  the judgment should be for Choices: a) the pilot's estate,  because the son was negligent in failing to properly extinguish the campfire.  b) the pilot's estate,  because the father is vicariously liable for the tortious conduct of his child.  c) the father and the son,  because the operator's reckless operation of his aircraft would be viewed as a superseding cause terminating the defendant's liability.  d) the father and the son,  because the son was only 12  years old and,  therefore,  cannot be deemed to have acted negligently.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to determine if the son's actions contributed to the chain of events leading to the crash.  The son failed to properly extinguish the campfire,  which led to a forest fire.  The forest fire caused the intense smoke that eventually led to the collision between the helicopter and the private plane.  Therefore,  the son's negligence played a role in the chain of events.
 Next,  I need to consider if the father is liable for the son's actions.  The father is vicariously liable for the son's tortious conduct,  as the son was acting within the scope of his parental duties.
 Finally,  I need to consider if the operator's actions terminated the defendants' liability.  The operator's reckless operation of his aircraft was a superseding cause,  but it did not terminate the defendants' liability.  The defendants' negligence still contributed to the chain of events leading to the crash.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'a'}

Input: A city ordinance forbids washing vehicles parked on city streets.  A man washes his car while it is parked on the street in front of his home.  The water forms a puddle in the street,  which freezes over during the night.  Early the next morning,  a car driving on the street slides on the ice and crashes into a tree.  If the driver of the car sues the man and asserts that the man was negligent per Se,  which of the following additional facts would help the man the most?  Choices: a) The man was not aware of the ordinance.  b) The city council enacted the ordinance after someone washing his car was hit by a passing truck.  c) The driver lives in the man's neighborhood and saw the man washing his car the day before the accident.  d) The driver is not a resident of the city.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to understand the claim that the man was negligent per Se.  Negligent per Se means that the man's actions were inherently dangerous and did not require any special knowledge or expertise to recognize the danger.
 To help the man,  I need to find additional facts that would show that the man did not intentionally create the danger or that the danger was not inherently dangerous.
 Option a) The man was not aware of the ordinance.  This fact could help the man because it shows that he did not intentionally violate the ordinance or create the danger.
 Option b) The city council enacted the ordinance after someone washing his car was hit by a passing truck.  This fact could also help the man because it suggests that the ordinance was created to prevent accidents like the one that occurred,  but it does not necessarily show that the man's actions were not negligent per Se.
 Option c) The driver lives in the man's neighborhood and saw the man washing his car the day before the accident.  This fact does not help the man because it only shows that the driver saw the man washing his car,  but it does not address the issue of whether the man's actions were negligent per Se.
 Option d) The driver is not a resident of the city.  This fact does not help the man because it is irrelevant to whether the man's actions were negligent per Se.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'a'}

Input: A plaintiff was seriously injured in a collision involving three trucks.  A sideswipe occurred between the plaintiff's pickup truck and a trailer truck as they passed in opposite directions.  The sideswipe caused the plaintiff's truck to careen down the road and into the path of a second trailer truck.  The driver of the second trailer truck was immediately killed.  Both of the trailer trucks were owned by the same transport company.  At trial,  the plaintiff called a witness to the collision to testify that he heard an unidentified female witness scream,  "Oh my God,  that trailer truck sideswiped that little pickup truck.  "The trial judge should rule the witness's testimony Choices: a) admissible as a declaration of existing state of mind.  b) admissible as an excited utterance.  c) inadmissible,  because it contains inadmissible opinion evidence.  d) inadmissible as hearsay not within any recognized exception.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to determine if the witness's testimony is hearsay.  Hearsay is a statement that is offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted in the statement,  and it is made by a witness who is not testifying at the hearing.  In this case,  the witness's testimony is about what they heard at the scene,  not their opinion about the event.  So,  it is hearsay.
 Next,  I need to determine if the testimony fits any of the recognized hearsay exceptions.  One exception is the excited utterance exception,  which allows a statement made by a witness while they are still in a disturbed emotional condition due to the event.  Another exception is the declaration of existing state of mind exception,  which allows a statement made by a witness about their then-existing mental condition.
 The witness's testimony is an account of what they heard at the scene,  not an opinion about the event.  So,  it does not fit the declaration of existing state of mind exception.  However,  the witness likely heard the scream while they were still emotionally disturbed by the event,  so it could fit the excited utterance exception.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A property owner agreed to sell one of his real estate parcels to a neighbor.  He wrote up an agreement of sale with the sale price of $200,000  and he signed the document.  The neighbor took it and returned with a bank check for the full amount,  demanding that the deed be tendered.  The property owner then decided that the terms were not reasonable and he returned the money and refused to tender a deed.  Neighbor sued for specific performance.  The property owner defended on the basis that the neighbor did not accept the agreement's terms and did not sign the document.  Neighbor sued for specific performance of the transaction.  Is the court likely to rule in favor of the neighbor?  Choices: a) No,  because the neighbor did not expressly state that he accepted the agreement.  b) No,  because the neighbor had to put his signature on the document to make it a binding contract.  c) Yes,  because neighbor manifested his assent by his conduct of tendering the full sale price,  at which point a contract existed.  d) Yes,  because the property owner created a binding contract when he prepared an agreement containing the agreed terms.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the elements of a contract.  A contract typically requires an offer,  acceptance,  consideration,  and an intention to create legal relations.
 In this case,  the property owner made an offer to sell the property for $200,000.  The neighbor tendered the full sale price,  which is consideration.  The intention to create legal relations is present as both parties are entering into a legal agreement.
 The next step is to determine if there was an acceptance of the offer.  The neighbor's act of tendering the full sale price can be seen as an acceptance of the offer,  as it is a manifestation of his assent to the terms of the agreement.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'c'}

Input: Ann owns a tract of land.  On August 1,2005,  Ann sells to Hunter and Willa,  a husband and wife,  an undivided one-half interest in this land for $100,000  (the entire consideration being paid by Hunter).  The deed to Hunter and Willa reads as follows: "To Hunger and Willa and their heirs as tenants by the entirety,  and not as joint tenants,  and not as tenants in common.  "On August 1,  2006,  Ann sells her remaining interest in the tract of land to Hunter and Brandon,  his brother,  for $125,000  (Hunter pays $80,000  of the purchase price,  and Brandon pays the balance).  The deed to Hunter and Brandon provides: "To Hunter and Brandon and their heirs as joint tenants and not as tenants in common.  "On August 1,  2007,  Hunter,  Willa,  and Brandon die in a common disaster,  and as a consequence,  the order of their deaths cannot be established by proof.  Hunter's will and Willa's will devise whatever interest in the land in question that is subject to disposition by their wills to their son.  Thus,  the son owns Choices: a) an undivided one-third interest in the land.  b) an undivided one-quarter interest in the land.  c) an undivided one-half interest in the land.  d) an undivided three-quarters interest in the land.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to determine the ownership interest of each party after the initial transactions.  Ann sells one-half interest to Hunter and Willa for $100,000,  so they each own a one-half interest in the land.
 Next,  Ann sells her remaining one-half interest to Hunter and Brandon for $125,000,  so Hunter now owns one-half interest and Brandon owns one-quarter interest in the land.
 Now,  I need to consider the nature of the ownership interests.  Hunter and Willa own their land as tenants by the entirety,  which means they own the land as a marital unit,  and their heirs inherit as a unit,  not separately.
 Hunter and Brandon own their land as joint tenants,  which means their heirs inherit separately.
 Since Hunter,  Willa,  and Brandon die in a common disaster,  their deaths are interdependent,  and the order of their deaths cannot be established.
 Hunter's will and Willa's will both devise their interests to their son.  Since Hunter and Willa owned their land as tenants by the entirety,  their son inherits their combined one-half interest as a unit.
 Therefore,  the son owns an undivided one-half interest in the land.  The correct answer is {'sol': 'c'}

Input: A law clerk normally worked from 9 :00  a.  m.  to5 :00  p.  m.  each day,  or an average of 40  hours per week.  One morning,  the law clerk came to the office at 9 :00  a.  m.  and started preparing a brief for an upcoming trial.  After completing his work at 5 :00  p.  m.  that afternoon,  he was about to leave the office when the senior partner of the law firm summoned him.  The senior partner told the law clerk that the law firm was representing an important client on an urgent matter that needed immediate research.  The law clerk was advised that he would be required to stay at the law office that night and prepare a memorandum.  When the law clerk hemmed and hawed,  the senior partner handed him the file and said,  "I don't care if you stay all night,  but you better have this memo on my desk by 8 :00  a.  m.  tomorrow.  "Following the senior partner's instructions,  the law clerk stayed at the office until 2 :00  a.  m.  preparing the memorandum.  By the time he finished,  the law clerk was totally exhausted after having worked a total of 17  hours that day.  Afterward,  the law clerk left the office and started to drive home.  Because of his fatigue,  he didn't see a pedestrian crossing the street.  His car struck the pedestrian,  seriously injuring herSThe pedestrian has asserted a tort action against the law firm to recover damages for her injuries.  Which of the following is the most likely result?  Choices: a) The pedestrian prevails,  because the law firm was negligent for requiring the law clerk to stay at the law office and finish the memorandum.  b) The pedestrian prevails,  because the law firm is legally responsible for its employees' actions.  c) The pedestrian loses,  because the actions of the law firm were not a cause-in-fact of the pedestrian's injuries.  d) The pedestrian loses,  because the law firm is not responsible for the law clerk's negligence in these circumstances.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the relationship between the law clerk's actions and the pedestrian's injuries.  The law clerk was fatigued after working 17  hours,  which likely affected his ability to drive safely.  This suggests that his fatigue could be a cause-in-fact of the pedestrian's injuries.
 Next,  I need to consider the legal principles at play.  One principle is that employers can be held vicariously responsible for the actions of their employees,  even if those actions are outside the scope of their normal duties.  In this case,  the law clerk was required to stay late and work on a memorandum,  which could be seen as an extension of his duties.
 Finally,  I need to consider the specific choices presented.  Choice a) suggests that the law firm was negligent for requiring the law clerk to stay at the law office and finish the memorandum.  This could be a factor,  but it doesn't directly address the issue of whether the law firm is legally responsible for the law clerk's actions.
 Choice b) suggests that the pedestrian prevails,  because the law firm is legally responsible for its employees' actions.  This choice directly addresses the issue of vicarious liability and seems to be the most likely result.
 Choice c) suggests that the pedestrian loses,  because the actions of the law firm were not a cause-in-fact of the pedestrian's injuries.  This choice seems unlikely,  given the clear connection between the law clerk's fatigue and the pedestrian's injuries.
 Choice d) suggests that the pedestrian loses,  because the law firm is not responsible for the law clerk's negligence in these circumstances.  This choice seems less likely than choice b),  as it does not address the issue of vicarious liability.
 Therefore,  the most likely result is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A man took money without permission from his employer to compensate himself for wages he honestly believed were owed to him.  The authorities arrested the man for felonious larceny,  a crime that is also called theft in some states.  The man defended on the basis that he had no intent to steal and only wanted his rightful compensation.  He filed a motion to dismiss,  relying essentially on proof that he had no intent to steal because he believed in good faith that it was his own property.  What will be the most likely decision of the court?  Choices: a) The charges will not be dismissed because his intent becomes irrelevant when he uses force to obtain possession of property.  b) The charges will be dismissed because the intent to steal is a required element of both theft and larceny and this man did not intend to steal because he thought that he had a right to the money.  c) The charges will be dismissed because he can raise the defense of necessity and it is always lawful to take what a person needs to survive.  d) The charges will not be dismissed because the man's right to the money was disputed and therefore his intent is irrelevant as compared to the employer's intent and belief.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the elements of theft and larceny.  In this case,  the man's intent to steal is not relevant because he believed in good faith that the money was his own property.  This belief negates the element of intent to steal.
 Next,  I need to consider the defense of necessity.  While the man may have needed the money to survive,  the defense of necessity does not automatically apply in this situation because the money was disputed by the employer.
 Finally,  I need to consider the employer's intent and belief.  The employer did not agree that the man had a right to the money,  so the man's belief that the money was his is not relevant to the employer's perspective.
 Therefore,  the most likely decision of the court is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A widget manufacturer and a widget retailer signed the following agreement:"The manufacturer promises to sell and the retailer promises to buy 10,000  widgets at $50  per 100.  One thousand widgets are to be delivered by the manufacturer on the first day of each of the next 10  months.  EACH MONTHLY DELIVERY ISA SEPARATE CONTRACT.  Payment to be made within 10  days of receipt of each shipment.  "The agreement between the manufacturer and the retailer may best be interpreted as Choices: a) a divisible contract.  b) an installment contract.  c) 10  separate contracts.  d) a requirements-output contract.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to understand the nature of the agreement.  The agreement states that the manufacturer will deliver 1000  widgets each month for 10  months,  and the retailer will buy these widgets at a certain price.
 Next,  I need to consider the characteristics of each type of contract.  A divisible contract is one that can be divided into smaller contracts,  but the agreement does not allow for this.  An installment contract is one where payments are made in installments,  and this is present in the agreement with payments being made within 10  days of receipt.  A requirements-output contract is one where the manufacturer produces goods based on the retailer's requirements,  but this is not the case here.
 Given the information provided,  the agreement may best be interpreted as {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A businessman was the owner of an idyllic lake and wooded area.  In 1980,  the businessman conveyed the land to the state "on the condition that" it be used as recreational property only.  Two years later,  the state decided that they wanted a small industrial park attached to the corner of the land.  The state went ahead and developed a small portion of the land as industrial space,  making it part of a larger industrial park that was adjacent to the land.  The businessman notified the state that he was the owner of the property because the state violated the conditions of the conveyance,  and that he was taking possession of the property back.  What was the interest that was created by the conveyance and can the businessman get the property back?  Choices: a) The interest created is a reverter,  and the property instantly reverts back to the grantor upon the occurrence of the specified violation.  b) The interest created is a fee simple subject to a condition subsequent,  and the original owner can get the property back only by taking affirmative steps to exercise his right of entry.  c) The interest is a fee simple subject to an executory limitation,  and if the condition occurs the property reverts in fee simple to a pre-designated third party.  d) The interest created is an indefeasible estate,  and the owner cannot do anything to enforce a condition that is against public policy and never enforceable in the first place.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to identify the type of interest created by the conveyance.  The businessman conveyed the land to the state with a condition that it be used as recreational property only.  This means that the interest created is a fee simple subject to a condition subsequent.
 Next,  I need to consider whether the state violated the condition.  The state developed a small portion of the land as industrial space,  which is not in line with the condition that the land be used as recreational property only.  Therefore,  the condition was violated.
 Now,  I need to determine if the businessman can get the property back.  Since the interest created is a fee simple subject to a condition subsequent,  the original owner can get the property back only by taking affirmative steps to exercise his right of entry.  This means that the businessman needs to take affirmative steps to exercise his right of entry to get the property back.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A retiree owned a 100 -acre farm.  For many years,  the retiree grew tobacco on a 10 -acre strip located in the northeast section of the property.  In March,  the retiree planted his annual tobacco crop,  which he usually harvested in early October.  In September,  the retiree sold his farm to a tobacco grower for $100,000.  At the time the retiree conveyed the property to the grower,  the tobacco crop was well developed and quite mature.  When the retiree and the grower entered into their land-sale agreement,  there was no mention of the status or ownership of the tobacco crop.  In early October,  after the grower took possession of the property,  the retiree contacted him and requested permission to harvest and remove the tobacco crop.  The grower refused to allow the retiree to re-enter the property.  The retiree brings suit against the grower seeking to re-enter the property and remove the tobacco crop that he had planted.  Which of the following is correct regarding the respective rights of the parties?  Choices: a) The retiree is entitled to remove the tobacco crop,  but he must pay the grower a reasonable value to enter the property,  thus gaining access to the crop.  b) The retiree is entitled to remove the tobacco crop and is not required to pay the grower for entering the property,  thus gaining access to the crop.  c) The retiree is not entitled to remove the tobacco crop and,  thus,  is not entitled to re-enter the property.  d) The retiree and the grower each have a colorable title to the tobacco crop,  and consequently,  there should be an equitable division of the proceeds from the sale of the crop between both parties.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the rights of the retiree and the grower regarding the tobacco crop.  The retiree planted the crop before the sale and it was well developed and mature at the time of the sale.  The grower did not have any role in planting or developing the crop.
 Next,  I need to consider the rights of the parties based on the law of easements.  An easement is a right to use someone else's property for a specific purpose,  such as accessing a property for the purpose of harvesting crops.  In this case,  the retiree had an easement to enter the property to harvest the tobacco crop.
 Now,  I need to consider the rights of the parties based on the law of prescriptive easements.  Prescriptive easements are created through continuous,  exercise of a right to use someone else's property without permission,  over a period of time,  usually 20 years.  In this case,  the retiree had been exercising his right to harvest the tobacco crop for many years before the sale.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'b'}

Input: A man purchased a house that needed substantial repairs.  The man financed the purchase of the house by borrowing funds from a bank.  He signed a note to the bank and secured repayment of the loan with a mortgage.  After purchasing the house,  the man borrowed money from his credit union to make the repairs.  The man signed a note to the credit union; this note was also secured by a mortgage on the house.  Both mortgages were promptly recorded in the order granted.  The man was personally liable on both loans.  The man moved into the house and made the necessary repairs.  He later defaulted on the debt to the bank,  and the bank initiated judicial foreclosure proceedings,  naming both the man and the credit union as parties to the action.  An outside party acquired the house at the foreclosure sale.  After the expenses of the sale and the balance due the bank have been paid,  $5,000  remains in the sale the bank have been paid,  $5,000  remains in the sale proceeds.  The outstanding balance of the credit union loan is $20,000.  The man and the credit union both claim the $5,000.  There is no applicable statute.  Who is entitled to the $5,000?  Choices: a) The credit union,  because the credit union has priority.  b) The credit union,  because the man is personally liable on the debt.  c) The man,  because of his equitable right of redemption.  d) The man,  because the outside party received title to the house subject to the second mortgage.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to determine the priority of the two mortgages.  The mortgages were granted in the order of their recording,  so the first mortgage recorded is the one from the bank,  and the second mortgage recorded is the one from the credit union.  Mortgages are typically given priority based on the order in which they are recorded,  so the bank's mortgage has priority over the credit union's mortgage.
 Next,  I need to consider the man's personal liability on the debt.  The man is personally liable on both loans,  but this does not affect the priority of the mortgages.
 Then,  I need to consider the man's equitable right of redemption.  The right of redemption allows the owner of a property to reclaim the property by paying the fair market value,  but this is not applicable in this case since the property was sold at a foreclosure sale,  not through a voluntary sale by the owner.
 Finally,  I need to consider the outside party's title to the house.  The outside party received title to the house subject to the second mortgage,  which means the credit union has a lien on the property.
 Therefore,  the correct answer is {'sol': 'a'}

Input: A doctor is charged with the murder of his wife.  The prosecution alleges that he murdered his wife by giving her a massive injection of succinylcholine while she was asleep.  Succinylcholine is a drug used in small quantities by anesthesiologists as a muscle relaxant.  The prosecution claims that the fatal dose given to the wife so totally relaxed her lung muscles that she suffocated.  During the trial,  a toxicologist,  who had no previous knowledge of the case,  sat in court and heard all of the evidence about the wife's death and autopsy.  As part of the doctor's defense,  his attorney calls the toxicologist to give his opinion on the cause of the wife's death.  May the toxicologist so testify?  Choices: a) Yes,  because he can identify the data upon which his opinion is based.  b) Yes,  because an expert may base his opinion on facts made known to him at the trial.  c) No,  because he has no personal knowledge of the wife's death.  d) No,  because the cause of death is an issue to be decided by the jury.  
 Output:
 First,  I need to consider the rules regarding expert testimony in a court of law.  One of the key rules is that an expert witness must have personal knowledge of the facts of the case.  In this case,  the toxicologist had no previous knowledge of the case and only heard the evidence presented during the trial.
